docs.lead_paragraph: Each year, 300,000 Americans have bypass surgery to improve blood flow to their hearts. Most of the operations succeed. But a minority of patients leave the hospital confused or forgetful, unable to think clearly or unable to concentrate. ''Pumpheads,'' some doctors privately call those patients, and the information shows that a third or more may be affected. As the term implies, doctors attributed the problems to the pump, the heart-lung machine that takes over during surgery when doctors literally stop a heart from beating so that they can repair its blocked vessels.

headline.main: Heart Pump and Brain Injury: A Riddle Deepens With Time

docs.abstract: Third or more of by-pass surgery patients become confused, forgetful or undergo personality changes after surgery to repair heart; doctors have been attributing changes to use of by-pass heart pump during surgery and many surgeons are now working off-pump; disagree as to cause of brain damage and some feel growing use of off-pump surgery is no more than marketing tool for doctors; Department of Veterans Affairs study, to be completed in 2007, should give most comprehensive look at problem to date, but until then patients and doctors must decide for themselves potential risks and rewards of different techniques; animal studies seem to confirm that heart-lung machines shower debris and tiny bubbles into brain; some doctors contend brain abnormalities are cause of pre-existing conditions made accute by heart surgery in general not just pump assisted surgery; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Each year, 300,000 Americans have bypass surgery to improve blood flow to their hearts. Most of the operations succeed. But a minority of patients leave the hospital confused or forgetful, unable to think clearly or unable to concentrate.   ...

docs.lead_paragraph: I drove west across an ocher sagebrush plain, past pinto ponies grazing next to a Pentecostal revival tent, past the ribbed, rutted dirt road that leads north to Chaco Canyon, the sacred, ancestral home of the Anasazi, the ancient ones. I was on the eastern edge of the vast Navajo Reservation, heading toward Crownpoint, a Navajo community of almost 3,000 people astride the Continental Divide about 100 miles northwest of Albuquerque. It is the administrative and educational hub of the Eastern Navajo Agency and the site of the Indian Health Service Hospital.

headline.main: Navajo Miners Battle a Deadly Legacy of Yellow Dust

docs.abstract: Dr John Fogerty, Indian Health Service medical officer, is known to Navajo in area as uranium doctor; extensive uranium mining in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Utah between 1940 and 1980 has created health crisis for those Indians who worked mining deadly yellow dust; compensation is being paid to those afflicted, but Navajo uranium miners run risk of lung cancer that is 28 times greater than Navajos not exposed to uranium; 500 uranium miners died of lung cancer between 1950 and 1990 with hundreds of additional deaths expected; Mitchell Capitan has founded Endaum, Eastern Navajo Dine Against Uranium Mining; organization is expecting final word soon from Nuclear Regulatory Commission as to future of uranium mining in area; map; photos (L)
docs.snippet: I drove west across an ocher sagebrush plain, past pinto ponies grazing next to a Pentecostal revival tent, past the ribbed, rutted dirt road that leads north to Chaco Canyon, the sacred, ancestral home of the Anasazi, the ancient ones.    I was on...

keywords.value: EASTER NAVAJO DINE AGAINST URANIUM MINING

docs.lead_paragraph: Prescription drugs to control the rising incidence of asthma in children and young adults appear to be underused, a new study suggests. After examining the records of 19,000 people, ages 5 to 21, researchers from the University of Michigan found that 16 percent had no prescriptions for short-acting medications and that 9 percent had no asthma prescriptions at all. The young people without prescriptions, the researchers found, were more likely to go to emergency rooms for treatment.
docs.abstract: University of Michigan researcher Dr Kevin J Dombkowski, studying records of 19,000 patients ages 5 to 21 who have asthma, finds that 16% had no prescriptions for fast-acting medication and 9% had no prescriptions at all; those with no recorded prescriptions visited emergency rooms 30% more often than those who had medicines (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical residents placed in a driving simulator when they were fatigued performed at least as badly as they did after they had consumed a drink or two, researchers have found. The study was prompted by anecdotal reports that residents, who often work extremely long hours in training, are prone to car accidents, said the lead author, Dr. Judith A. Owens of the Brown Medical School.
docs.abstract: Dr Judith A Owens, Brown University Medical School researcher, leads study that compares driving ability while sleep deprived to driving while under influence of alcohol; finds sleep deprived subjects faired as badly or worse than those with alcohol in their blood; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: What happens if someone drinks eight liters of soda a day? Nothing good, surely. But for a 63-year-old who favored a citrus drink called Ruby Red Squirt, one result was rare and unpleasant skin lesions. In a letter published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, doctors described how the patient arrived at the MetroHealth Medical Center in Cleveland with ulcerations on his hands and fingers.

headline.main: A Few Drinks (of Soda) Too Many

docs.abstract: Debra M Jih, Cleveland MetroHealth Medical Center doctor, reports in New England Journal of Medicine process of determing cause of patient's bromoderma, or skin lesions caused by bromine; discovered eight litre per day habit of drinking Ruby Red Squirt combined with bromine sensitivity was cause; cartoon (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans consider the problem of overweight children and teenagers to be a growing health concern, and cite a mixture of a less active lifestyle, more electronic diversion and less healthy diet as the causes, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. The public is clearly aware of a rise in weight problems among the young. A large majority, 87 percent of those polled, say there are more overweight children and teenagers these days than there were when they were young. Two-thirds of the adults in the Times/CBS News poll agree with experts that overweight children and teenagers are a major health problem.

headline.main: More Children Are Obese, and More Americans Know It

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll shows that adults are aware that there are more overweight children now then several years ago and they attribute change to variety of factors; lack of healthy foods, increasingly sedentary life styles and availability and consumption of fast foods are cited as top reasons children weigh more; Dr Nancy F Krebs, American Academy of Pediatrics' Committee on Nutrition chairwoman, emphasizes that there are health and emotional risks for overweight children (M)
docs.snippet: Americans consider the problem of overweight children and teenagers to be a growing health concern, and cite a mixture of a less active lifestyle, more electronic diversion and less healthy diet as the causes, according to the latest New York...

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the only time I was afraid to touch a patient. When I saw her, she seemed to have symptoms of a disease that had spread quickly where she lived and had killed up to two-thirds of the population over several decades.

headline.main: With Disease, Fear Knows No Cultural Boundaries

docs.abstract: Emerging infectious diseases have caused medical community to address personal fears in treating severly ill patients and functioning effectvely around potentially deadly viruses; attitude of those treating kuru, prion disease most often transmitted through cannibalistic practices, is compared to reaction of western culture to mad cow disease before threat to humans was identified; narrow bridge between overreacting to possible outbreak and denying existence of infectious threat may be one of medicine's greatest challenges; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: It was the only time I was afraid to touch a patient.    When I saw her, she seemed to have symptoms of a disease that had spread quickly where she lived and had killed up to two-thirds of the population over several decades.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cervical cancer has been perhaps the biggest success story in the long-running war against cancer. Once the leading cause of cancer deaths in women, cervical cancer will this year account for 4,100 deaths, not even 1 percent of cancer deaths among American women. Credit for the progress goes almost entirely to the Pap smear, a test now administered to 50 million Americans a year.

headline.main: Pap Test, Champion Against Cervical Cancer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on success of Pap test in greatly reducing death from cervical cancer; outlines new recommended Amercian Cancer Society guidelines for test usage and screening; less than one percent of cancer deaths in women are now result of cervical cancer; changes in suggested frequency of pap test and addition of HPV, human papillomavirus, test are discussed; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: Cervical cancer has been perhaps the biggest success story in the long-running war against cancer.    Once the leading cause of cancer deaths in women, cervical cancer will this year account for 4,100 deaths, not even 1 percent of cancer deaths among...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Power of 10: The Once-a-Week Slow Motion Fitness Revolution,'' by Adam Zickerman and Bill Schley. HarperCollins, $24.95. ''The Slow Burn Fitness Revolution,'' by Fredrick Hahn, Dr. Michael R. Eades and Dr. Mary Dan Eades. Broadway Books, $25. Exercise regimens that promise to get the out of shape into better shape than an athlete and in shorter time continue to find their way into books, rivaling in repetition, imaginative spin and new packaging only those on diets, natural medicines and meditation techniques.
docs.abstract: Book, Power of 10: Once-a-Week Slow Motion Fitness Revolution, by authors Adam Zickerman and Bill Schley emphasizes weight training with extreme slowness to maximize work on muscles in only few repetitions; Dr Michael R Eades, Dr Mary Dan Eades and Fredrick Hahne author book Slow Burn Fitness Revolution, which is also guide to fitness routine that emphasizes targeted, slow muscle work; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who play sports like basketball that involve extensive jumping and pivoting are known to be much more susceptible to knee ligament injuries than men. A new report suggests some reasons and what women can do about the problem. Writing in The Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery this month, researchers from the University of Michigan said men appeared better able to contract the muscles that support the knee and protect its ligaments.
docs.abstract: University of Michigan researcher Dr Edward M Wojtys study, published in Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery, finds that females are more likely to suffer knee ligament injuries than men; suggests that athletic training for women should be different then for men; cartoon (S)
